DataElement.preferredDefinition: The anatomic location to which a cancer has spread.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A disease process that is increasing in scope or severity._Named locations of or within the body.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Cancer that is increasing in scope or severity.

Concepts.definition: A clinical, pathologic, and/or molecular finding indicating that the course of a disease is worsening in terms of extent or severity.

Property.preferredDefinition: Named locations of, or within, the body.

Concepts.definition: Named locations of or within the body.

Property.changeDescription: Updated to point to NCI Thesaurus concept code.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 8/29/17 jk DEC released; added registration status per Round 5 finalization task.  7/25/17 tt New DEC per Rnd 5 finalization task.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Named locations of or within the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.

Concepts.definition: The structural organ comprised of specialized connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.

Concepts.definition: The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.

Concepts.definition: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.

Concepts.definition: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A lymph node located distant to the anatomic site of interest.

Concepts.definition: A lymph node located distant to the anatomic site of interest.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 7/28/23 Added missing concept per cleanup activities cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Far apart in space, time, or relevance from a point of origin.: An organ that constitutes the external surface of the body.  It consists of the epidermis, dermis, and skin appendages.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: Beneath the skin.

Concepts.definition: Far apart in space from a point of origin on the body.
An organ that constitutes the external surface of the body. It consists of the epidermis, dermis, and skin appendages.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
Beneath the skin.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concet annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 01/30/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Atomic sites other than those already listed.

Concepts.definition: Atomic sites other than those already listed.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Ipsilateral supraclavicular nodes
A large organ located in the upper abdomen. The liver cleanses the blood and aids in digestion by secreting bile.

Concepts.definition: A triangular-shaped organ located under the diaphragm in the right hypochondrium. It is the largest internal organ of the body, weighting up to 2 kg. Metabolism and bile secretion are its main functions. It is composed of cells which have the ability to regenerate.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2023.3.7 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0002119. ak

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Local-regional (including ipsilateral breast; chest wall; axillary, internal mammary, and infraclavicular nodes; local-regional skin and subcutaneous tissue)

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Local-regional (including ipsilateral breast; chest wall; axillary, internal mammary, and infraclavicular nodes; local-regional skin and subcutaneous tissue)
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Of or belonging to both a local and regional area of the body.

Concepts.definition: Of or belonging to both a local and regional area of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

Concepts.definition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 7/28/23 Added missing concept per cleanup activities cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Contralateral breast
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: The part of the nervous system that consists of the brain, spinal cord, and meninges.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
The part of the nervous system that consists of the brain, spinal cord, and meninges.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/05/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (PLOOR-a) A thin layer of tissue covering the lungs and the wall of the chest cavity to protect and cushion the lungs. A small amount of fluid that acts as a lubricant allows the lungs to move smoothly in the chest cavity during breathing.

Concepts.definition: The tissue that lines the wall of the thoracic cavity and the surface of the lungs.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Atomic sites other than those already listed.

Concepts.definition: Atomic sites other than those already listed.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity, which may be serous, hemorrhagic, or the result of tumor metastasis to the peritoneum.

Concepts.definition: The accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity, which may be serous, hemorrhagic, or the result of tumor metastasis to the peritoneum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (PAIR-ih-toe-NEE-um) The tissue that lines the abdominal wall and covers most of the organs in the abdomen.

Concepts.definition: The tissue that lines the wall of the abdominal cavity, intestine, mesentery, and pelvic organs. It consists of the parietal peritoneum and the visceral peritoneum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Pleural effusion

Concepts.definition: Increased amounts of fluid within the pleural cavity. Symptoms include shortness of breath, cough, and chest pain. It is usually caused by lung infections, congestive heart failure, pleural and lung tumors, connective tissue disorders, and trauma.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 20212.12.13 Alt VM Named added for ticket requestCADSR0001786. ak

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An organ that constitutes the external surface of the body. It consists of the epidermis, dermis, and skin appendages.

Concepts.definition: An organ that constitutes the external surface of the body. It consists of the epidermis, dermis, and skin appendages.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: LYMPH NODES, SPECIFY
A lymph node that drains lymph from a region of interest.

Concepts.definition: A lymph node that drains lymph from a region of interest.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 7/13/23 Added missing concept per cleanup activities cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Presence of tumor found within the same lung as the primary disease site
Tumor present in the opposite lung or at a point distant from the primary site within the same lung
The anatomic location of a primary tumor.

Concepts.definition: The anatomic location of a primary tumor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not stated explicitly or in detail.

Concepts.definition: Not stated explicitly or in detail.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has but two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

Concepts.definition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Subcutaneous/Skin
An organ that produces lymphocytes, filters the blood, stores blood cells, and destroys those that are aging. It is located on the left side of the abdomen near the stomach. (OCC)

Concepts.definition: An organ that is part of the hematopoietic and immune systems. It is composed of the white pulp and the red pulp and is surrounded by a capsule. It is located in the left hypochondriac region. Its functions include lymphocyte production, blood cell storage, and blood cell destruction.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of the two bean-shaped organs located on each side of the spine in the retroperitoneum. The right kidney is located below the liver and the left kidney below the diaphragm. The kidneys filter and secret the metabolic products and minerals from the blood, thus maintaining the homeostasis. On the superior pole of each kidney there is an adrenal gland. Each kidney and adrenal gland is surrounded by fat.

Concepts.definition: One of the two bean-shaped organs located on each side of the spine in the retroperitoneum. The right kidney is located below the liver and the left kidney below the diaphragm. The kidneys filter and secrete metabolic products and minerals from the blood, thus maintaining homeostasis. On the superior pole of each kidney there is an adrenal gland. Each kidney and adrenal gland is surrounded by fat.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Parotid gland

Concepts.definition: The largest of the three paired salivary glands, located in front of the ear.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Submandibular gland

Concepts.definition: One of a pair of major salivary glands located below the floor of the mouth.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An organ that is part of the lymphatic system, in which T lymphocytes grow and multiply. The thymus is in the chest behind the breastbone.

Concepts.definition: A bi-lobed organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is located in the upper anterior portion of the chest, behind the sternum. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and fewer epithelial cells. Connective tissue septa separate the lobes into lobules. The lobules contain an outer portion (cortical zone) which is rich in lymphocytes and an inner portion (medullary zone) which is rich in epithelial cells. It is an organ essential for the development of the immune system. Its function is the maturation of the progenitor lymphoid cells to thymocytes and subsequently to mature T-cells. It reaches its greatest weight at puberty and subsequently begins to involute.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An endocrine gland located at the base of the neck that produces and secretes thyroxine and other hormones. Thyroxine is important for metabolic control.

Concepts.definition: An endocrine gland located at the base of the neck that produces and secretes thyroxine and other hormones. Thyroxine is important for metabolic control.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 7/13/23 Added missing concepts per cleanujp activities cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Either of the paired male reproductive glands that produce the male germ cells and the male hormones.

Concepts.definition: Either of the paired male reproductive glands that produce the male germ cells and the male hormones.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 7/13/23 Added missing concepts per cleanup activities cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of the paired female reproductive glands containing the ova or germ cells; the ovary's stroma is a vascular connective tissue containing numbers of ovarian follicles enclosing the ova; surrounding this stroma is a more condensed layer of stroma called the tunica albuginea.

Concepts.definition: One of the paired female reproductive glands containing the ova or germ cells; the ovary's stroma is a vascular connective tissue containing numbers of ovarian follicles enclosing the ova.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The organ located between the esophagus and the small intestine where digestion of food occurs before passing to the small intestine.

Concepts.definition: The primary organ of food digestion. It is located under the diaphragm, between the liver and the spleen as well as between the esophagus and the small intestine.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The section of the intestines between the pylorus and cecum. The small intestine is approximately 20 feet long and consists of the duodenum, the jejunum, and the ileum. Its main function is to absorb nutrients from food as the food is transported to the large intestine.

Concepts.definition: The section of the intestines between the pylorus and cecum. The small intestine is approximately 20 feet long and consists of the duodenum, the jejunum, and the ileum. Its main function is to absorb nutrients from food as the food is transported to the large intestine.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 7/13/23 Added missing concept per cleanup activities cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The part of the large intestine measured from the cecum to the rectum consisting of ascending, transverse, descending and sigmoid portions. The purpose of the colon is to remove water from digested food prior to excretion.

Concepts.definition: The part of the large intestine measured from the cecum to the rectum consisting of ascending, transverse, descending and sigmoid portions. The purpose of the colon is to remove water from digested food prior to excretion.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A lymph node located distant to the anatomic site of interest.

Concepts.definition: A lymph node located distant to the anatomic site of interest.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 7/28/23 Added missing concept per cleanup activities cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Spine - parenchymal
CNS - epidural
CNS - leptomeninges
CNS - vitreal
Brain - parenchymal
Within the abdomen.

Concepts.definition: Within the abdomen.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 7/7/23 Added missing concept per cleanup efforts cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A bean-shaped organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is part of the lymphatic system and is found throughout the body. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and its main function is immune protection.

Concepts.definition: A bean-shaped organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is part of the lymphatic system and is found throughout the body. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and its main function is immune protection.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 01/30/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The main information-processing organs of the nervous system, consisting of the brain, spinal cord, and meninges.

Concepts.definition: The part of the nervous system that consists of the brain, spinal cord, and meninges.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: On or relating to the opposite side of the body._One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

Concepts.definition: On or relating to the opposite side of the body.

One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No Value Exists

A lymph node located in the mediastinum. Mediastinal lymph nodes are arranged in three groups, one on the lateral, another on the medial, and a third on the anterior aspect of the vessels; the third group is, however, sometimes absent.

Concepts.definition: A lymph node located in the mediastinum. Mediastinal lymph nodes are arranged in three groups, one on the lateral, another on the medial, and a third on the anterior aspect of the vessels; the third group is, however, sometimes absent.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lymph nodes located above the clavicle (collarbone).

Concepts.definition: A lymph node which is located above the clavicle.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: On or relating to the opposite side of the body._Increased amounts of fluid within the pleural cavity. Symptoms include shortness of breath, cough, and chest pain. It is usually caused by lung infections, congestive heart failure, pleural and lung tumors, connective tissue disorders, and trauma.

Concepts.definition: On or relating to the opposite side of the body.

Increased amounts of fluid within the pleural cavity. Symptoms include shortness of breath, cough, and chest pain. It is usually caused by lung infections, congestive heart failure, pleural and lung tumors, connective tissue disorders, and trauma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: On or relating to the opposite side of the body._A lymph node which is located above the clavicle.

Concepts.definition: On or relating to the opposite side of the body.
A lymph node which is located above the clavicle.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 7/7/23 Added missing concepts per cleanup efforts cjl.

PermissibleValues.value: Separate lobe of the ipsilateral lung
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Separate lobe of the ipsilateral lung

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Separate lobe of the ipsilateral lung
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Separate lobe of the ipsilateral lung
The two innermost layers of tissue that cover the brain and spinal cord, the arachnoid mater and the pia mater.

Concepts.definition: The two innermost layers of tissue that cover the brain and spinal cord, the arachnoid mater and the pia mater.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Paired glands situated in the retroperitoneal tissues at the superior pole of each kidney.

Concepts.definition: A flattened, roughly triangular body resting upon the upper end of each kidney; it is one of the ductless glands furnishing internal secretions (epinephrine and norepinephrine from the medulla and steroid hormones from the cortex).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Fluid collection within the pericardial sac, usually due to inflammation.

Concepts.definition: Fluid collection within the pericardial sac, usually due to inflammation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The part of a bronchus that remains after resection.

Concepts.definition: The part of a bronchus that remains after resection.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 7/7/23 Added missing concept per cleanup activities cjl.

PermissibleValues.value: Lung parenchyma adjacent to primary tumor
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Lung parenchyma adjacent to primary tumor

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Lung parenchyma adjacent to primary tumor
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lung parenchyma adjacent to primary tumor
Ipsilateral hilar mediastinum (nodal)
Contralateral hilar mediastinum (nodal)

Having to do with the same side of the body._Increased amounts of fluid within the pleural cavity. Symptoms include shortness of breath, cough, and chest pain. It is usually caused by lung infections, congestive heart failure, pleural and lung tumors, connective tissue disorders, and trauma.

Concepts.definition: Having to do with the same side of the body.

Increased amounts of fluid within the pleural cavity. Symptoms include shortness of breath, cough, and chest pain. It is usually caused by lung infections, congestive heart failure, pleural and lung tumors, connective tissue disorders, and trauma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Urothelial Tract
The distensible sac-like organ that functions as a reservoir of urine, collecting from the kidneys and eliminating via the urethra.

Concepts.definition: The distensible sac-like organ that functions as a reservoir of urine, collecting from the kidneys and eliminating via the urethra.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The bony, basin-shaped structure formed by the hipbones and the base of the backbone supporting the lower limbs in humans.

Concepts.definition: The bony, basin-shaped structure formed by the hipbones and the base of the backbone supporting the lower limbs in humans.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The portion of the digestive canal between the pharynx and stomach. It is about 25 cm long and consists of three parts: the cervical part, from the cricoid cartilage to the thoracic inlet; thoracic part, from thoracic inlet to the diaphragm; and abdominal part, below the diaphragm to the cardiac opening of the stomach.

Concepts.definition: The portion of the digestive canal between the pharynx and stomach. It is about 25 cm long and consists of three parts: the cervical part, from the cricoid cartilage to the thoracic inlet; thoracic part, from thoracic inlet to the diaphragm; and abdominal part, below the diaphragm to the cardiac opening of the stomach.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The lower part of the pharynx that connects to the esophagus.

Concepts.definition: The lower part of the pharynx that connects to the esophagus.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The organ of voice production; the part of the respiratory tract between the pharynx and the trachea; it consists of a framework of cartilages and elastic membranes housing the vocal folds and the muscles which control the position and tension of these elements.

Concepts.definition: The cartilaginous structure of the respiratory tract between the pharynx and the trachea. It contains elastic vocal cords required for sound production.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The part of the pharynx in the back of the throat, at and above the soft palate. The nasopharynx is continuous with the nasal passages.

Concepts.definition: The part of the pharynx in the back of the throat, at and above the soft palate. The nasopharynx is continuous with the nasal passages.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The cavity lying at the upper end of the alimentary canal, bounded on the outside by the lips and inside by the oropharynx and containing in humans the tongue, gums, and teeth.

Concepts.definition: The cavity located at the upper end of the alimentary canal, behind the teeth and gums that is bounded on the outside by the lips, above by the hard and soft palates and below by the tongue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (or-o-FAIR-inks) The middle part of the throat that includes the soft palate, the base of the tongue, and the tonsils.

Concepts.definition: The part of the pharynx between the soft palate and the upper portion of the epiglottis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An organ behind the lower part of the stomach that is the shape of a fish and about the size of a hand. It is a compound gland composed of both exocrine and endocrine tissues. The endocrine pancreas makes insulin so that the body can use glucose (sugar) for energy. The exocrine pancreas makes enzymes that help the body digest food. Spread all over the pancreas are areas called the Islets of Langerhans. The cells in these areas each have a special purpose. The alpha cells make glucagon, which raises the level of glucose in the blood; the beta cells make insulin; the delta cells make somatostatin. There are also PP cells and D1 cells, about which little is known.

Concepts.definition: An organ behind the lower part of the stomach that is the shape of a fish and about the size of a hand. It is a compound gland composed of both exocrine and endocrine tissues. The endocrine pancreas makes insulin so that the body can use glucose (sugar) for energy. The exocrine pancreas makes enzymes that help the body digest food. Spread all over the pancreas are areas called the Islets of Langerhans. The cells in these areas each have a special purpose. The alpha cells make glucagon, which raises the level of glucose in the blood; the beta cells make insulin; the delta cells make somatostatin. There are also PP cells and D1 cells, about which little is known.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated concept definition to match current NCIt. 4.5.18 mc

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: For oncology, area of the body generally construed to comprise base of skull and facial bones, sinuses, orbits, salivary glands, oral cavity, oropharynx, larynx, thyroid, facial and neck musculature and lymph nodes draining these areas.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

For oncology, an area of the body generally construed to comprise the base of skull and facial bones, sinuses, orbits, salivary glands, oral cavity, oropharynx, larynx, thyroid, facial and neck musculature and lymph nodes draining these areas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Other distant site, specify
Meningitis carcinomatosa
A malignant neoplasm that has spread to the brain from another anatomic site or system. The majority are carcinomas (usually lung or breast carcinomas).

Concepts.longName: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Brain
Concepts.definition: A malignant neoplasm that has spread to the brain from another anatomic site or system. The majority are carcinomas (usually lung or breast carcinomas).

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Skin nodes other than specified on local / regional recurrence page
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Skin nodes other than specified on local / regional recurrence page
The framework that supports the soft tissues of vertebrate animals and protects many of their internal organs. The skeletons of vertebrates are made of bone and/or cartilage.

Concepts.definition: The collection of bones and tissues, including ligaments and cartilage, that compose the rigid internal framework of the human body, and which serves a multitude of functions, including structural support, movement, protection, production of blood cells, storage of ions, and endocrine regulation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A bean-shaped organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is part of the lymphatic system and is found throughout the body. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and its main function is immune protection.: To come back or to return.

Concepts.definition: A bean-shaped organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is part of the lymphatic system and is found throughout the body. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and its main function is immune protection.
Happening again (especially at regular intervals).

Concepts.definition: Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.

Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

Concepts.definition: Having to do with the same side of the body.

One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 7/7/23 Added missing concepts per cleanup efforts cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having, relating to, or consisting of more than one individual, element, part, or other component; manifold.: Named locations of or within the body.: The worsening of a disease over time.

Concepts.definition: Having, relating to, or consisting of more than one individual, element, part, or other component; manifold.
Named locations of or within the body.
A process that manifests as the worsening of a disease over time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: On or relating to the opposite side (of the body): One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

Concepts.definition: On or relating to the opposite side of the body.
One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Derived as a result of a primary condition; not direct or immediate; of second rank or importance or value.: A tumor at the original site of origin.

Concepts.definition: Derived as a result of a primary condition; not direct or immediate; of second rank or importance or value.
A tumor at the original site of origin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Situated farthest from a point of attachment or origin, as of a limb or bone; or directed away from the midline of the body.

Concepts.definition: Situated farthest from a point of attachment or origin, as of a limb or bone; or directed away from the midline of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Of or belonging to a restricted area or locality.

Concepts.definition: Of or belonging to a restricted area or locality.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Of or belonging to a broader area or region of the body.

Concepts.definition: Of or belonging to a broader area or region of the body.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Named locations of, or within, the body.

Concepts.definition: Named locations of or within the body.
